Basic Entropy Inequalities

Posted on 2021-07-07 Edited on 2022-01-17

Let XXX and YYY be two discrete random variables.

Relative Entropy

Given a distribution ppp, if we encode it with a distribution qqq (with the same support), the expected coding length is roughly

∑ipilog⁡1qi \sum_i p_i \log \frac{1}{q_i} i∑​pi​logqi​1​

The cost over the optimal coding is given by

D(p∣∣q)≐∑ipilog⁡1qi−∑ipilog⁡1pi=∑ipilog⁡piqi \mathbf{D} (p || q) \doteq \sum_i p_i \log \frac{1}{q_i} - \sum_i p_i \log \frac{1}{p_i} = \sum_i p_i \log \frac{p_i}{q_i} D(p∣∣q)≐i∑​pi​logqi​1​−i∑​pi​logpi​1​=i∑​pi​logqi​pi​​

By definition, we know that this gap is always non-negative.
We can prove it rigorously algebraically. We show two different approaches here.

  1. By that f(x)=xlog⁡xf(x) = x \log xf(x)=xlogx is convex for x≥0x \ge 0x≥0, we have

    D(p∣∣q)=∑ipilog⁡piqi=∑iqi⋅piqilog⁡piqi≥(∑iqi⋅piqi)log⁡(∑iqi⋅piqi)=0\begin{aligned} \mathbf{D}(p || q) &= \sum_i p_i \log \frac{p_i}{q_i} \\ &= \sum_i q_i \cdot \frac{p_i}{q_i} \log \frac{p_i}{q_i} \\ &\ge \left( \sum_i q_i \cdot \frac{p_i}{q_i} \right) \log \left( \sum_i q_i \cdot \frac{p_i}{q_i} \right) \\ &= 0 \end{aligned} D(p∣∣q)​=i∑​pi​logqi​pi​​=i∑​qi​⋅qi​pi​​logqi​pi​​≥(i∑​qi​⋅qi​pi​​)log(i∑​qi​⋅qi​pi​​)=0​

  2. By that f(x)=−log⁡xf(x) = -\log xf(x)=−logx is convex (for x≥0x \ge 0x≥0 ), we have

    D(p∣∣q)=∑i−pilog⁡qipi≥−log⁡(∑ipi⋅qipi)=0\begin{aligned} \mathbf{D}(p || q) &= \sum_i - p_i \log \frac{q_i}{p_i} \\ &\ge -\log \left( \sum_i p_i \cdot \frac{q_i}{p_i} \right) \\ &= 0 \end{aligned} D(p∣∣q)​=i∑​−pi​logpi​qi​​≥−log(i∑​pi​⋅pi​qi​​)=0​

Theorem (Maximum Value). Let XXX be a random variable taking values in an alphabet Ω\OmegaΩ. Then

H(X)≤log⁡∣Ω∣ \mathbf{H}(X) \le \log | \Omega | H(X)≤log∣Ω∣

The inequality is saturated if and only if XXX is a uniform random variable on Ω\OmegaΩ.

Proof. Let UUU be a uniform random variable on Ω\OmegaΩ.
Then

D(X∥U)=∑p(x)log⁡p(x)1/∣Ω∣=log⁡∣Ω∣−H(x)≥0. \mathbf{D}( X \Vert U ) = \sum p(x) \log \frac{ p(x) }{ 1 / | \Omega | } = \log | \Omega | - \mathbf{H}(x) \ge 0. D(X∥U)=∑p(x)log1/∣Ω∣p(x)​=log∣Ω∣−H(x)≥0.

□\square□

Joint Entropy

Definition. The joint entropy of XXX and YYY is

H(X,Y)=∑x,yp(x,y)log⁡1p(x,y) \mathbf{H}(X, Y) = \sum_{x, y} p(x, y) \log \frac{1}{ p(x, y) } H(X,Y)=x,y∑​p(x,y)logp(x,y)1​

If XXX and YYY are independent, then

H(X,Y)=H(X)+H(Y). \mathbf{H}(X, Y) = \mathbf{H}(X) + \mathbf{H}(Y). H(X,Y)=H(X)+H(Y).

Conditional Entropy

Definition. The conditional entropy of XXX given Y=yY = yY=y is the entropy of the probability distribution p(X∣Y=y)p(X \mid Y = y)p(X∣Y=y)

H(X∣Y=y)=∑xp(x∣y)log⁡1p(x∣y) \mathbf{H}(X \mid Y = y) = \sum_x p(x \mid y) \log \frac{1}{ p(x \mid y) } H(X∣Y=y)=x∑​p(x∣y)logp(x∣y)1​

Definition. The conditional entropy of XXX given YYY, is the average, over yyy, the conditional entropy of XXX given yyy

H(X∣Y)=∑yp(y)H(X∣Y=y)=∑x,yp(x,y)log⁡1p(x∣y). \mathbf{H}(X \mid Y) = \sum_y p(y) \mathbf{H}(X \mid Y = y) = \sum_{x, y} p(x , y) \log \frac{1}{ p(x \mid y) }. H(X∣Y)=y∑​p(y)H(X∣Y=y)=x,y∑​p(x,y)logp(x∣y)1​.

Theorem (Zero Conditional Entropy). Suppose that XXX and YYY have the same support. H(X∣Y)=0\mathbf{H}(X \mid Y) = 0H(X∣Y)=0 if and only if XXX is a function of YYY.

Proof. If

H(X∣Y)=∑yp(y)H(X∣Y=y)=0. \mathbf{H}(X \mid Y) = \sum_y p(y) \mathbf{H}(X \mid Y = y) = 0. H(X∣Y)=y∑​p(y)H(X∣Y=y)=0.

Then either p(y)=0p(y) = 0p(y)=0 or H(X∣Y=y)=0\mathbf{H}(X \mid Y = y) = 0H(X∣Y=y)=0 for all yyy.
On the other hand, for each yyy, if p(y)>0p(y) > 0p(y)>0, then

H(X∣Y=y)=∑xp(x∣y)log⁡1p(x∣y)=0, \mathbf{H}(X \mid Y = y) = \sum_x p(x \mid y) \log \frac{1}{ p(x \mid y) } = 0, H(X∣Y=y)=x∑​p(x∣y)logp(x∣y)1​=0,

Then either p(x∣y)=0p(x \mid y) = 0p(x∣y)=0 or log⁡1p(x∣y)=0\log \frac{1}{ p(x \mid y) } = 0logp(x∣y)1​=0.
It follows that there is a unique xxx, for which p(x∣y)=1p(x \mid y) = 1p(x∣y)=1.

Conversely, if XXX is a function of YYY, for each yyy such that p(y)>0p(y) > 0p(y)>0, there is a unique xxx such that p(x∣y)=1p(x \mid y) = 1p(x∣y)=1.
Hence, H(X∣Y=y)=0\mathbf{H}(X \mid Y = y) = 0H(X∣Y=y)=0 and H(X∣Y)=0H(X \mid Y) = 0H(X∣Y)=0.

□\square□

Mutual Information

Definition. The mutual information between XXX and YYY is

I(X;Y)=Ep(x,y)[log⁡p(x,y)p(x)p(y)]=D(p(x,y)∥p(x)p(y)). I(X; Y) = \mathbb{E}_{p(x, y) } \left[ \log \frac{ p(x, y)}{p(x) p(y) } \right] = \mathbf{D}( p(x, y) \Vert p(x) p(y) ). I(X;Y)=Ep(x,y)​[logp(x)p(y)p(x,y)​]=D(p(x,y)∥p(x)p(y)).

The definition is symmetric and it holds that I(X;Y)=I(Y;X)I(X; Y) = I(Y; X)I(X;Y)=I(Y;X).
If we know p(x,y)p(x,y)p(x,y), we use in expectation Ep(x,y)[log⁡1p(x,y)]\mathbb{E}_{p(x, y) } \left[ \log \frac{1} { p(x, y)} \right]Ep(x,y)​[logp(x,y)1​] bits to describe them.
If we know only p(x)p(x)p(x) and p(y)p(y)p(y), the mutual information measures the bits we waste.

∑p(x,y)log⁡p(x,y)p(x)p(y)=∑p(x,y)(log⁡1p(x)+log⁡1p(y)−log⁡1p(x,y))=H(X)+H(Y)−H(X,Y) \small \begin{aligned} &\sum p(x, y) \log \frac{ p(x, y)}{p(x) p(y) } \\ =& \sum p(x, y) \left( \log \frac{ 1 }{p(x)} + \log \frac{ 1 }{p(y)} - \log \frac{ 1 }{p(x, y)} \right) \\ =& \mathbf{H} ( X ) + \mathbf{H} ( Y ) - \mathbf{H} ( X, Y ) \end{aligned} ==​∑p(x,y)logp(x)p(y)p(x,y)​∑p(x,y)(logp(x)1​+logp(y)1​−logp(x,y)1​)H(X)+H(Y)−H(X,Y)​

Further, mutual information measures the average reduction of randomness of XXX that results from learning the value of YYY.

∑p(x,y)log⁡p(x,y)p(x)p(y)=∑p(x,y)log⁡p(x∣y)p(x)=H(X)−H(X∣Y). \small \begin{aligned} \sum p(x, y) \log \frac{ p(x, y)}{p(x) p(y) } &=\sum p(x, y) \log \frac{ p(x | y)}{p(x) } \\ &= \mathbf{H} ( X ) - \mathbf{H} ( X \mid Y). \end{aligned} ∑p(x,y)logp(x)p(y)p(x,y)​​=∑p(x,y)logp(x)p(x∣y)​=H(X)−H(X∣Y).​

In this sense, the mutual information quantifies the dependence between XXX and YYY.
It measures how much knowing one random variable reduces the uncertainty about the other random variable.

Similarly, we can prove that

∑p(x,y)log⁡p(x,y)p(x)p(y)=∑p(x,y)log⁡p(x∣y)p(x)=H(Y)−H(X∣Y). \small \begin{aligned} \sum p(x, y) \log \frac{ p(x, y)}{p(x) p(y) } &=\sum p(x, y) \log \frac{ p(x | y)}{ p(x) } \\ &=\mathbf{H} ( Y ) - \mathbf{H} ( X \mid Y). \end{aligned} ∑p(x,y)logp(x)p(y)p(x,y)​​=∑p(x,y)logp(x)p(x∣y)​=H(Y)−H(X∣Y).​

I(X;Y)≥0\mathbf{I}(X; Y) \ge 0I(X;Y)≥0.

Proof.

I(X;Y)=D(p(x,y)∣p(x)p(y))≥0 \mathbf{I}(X; Y) = \mathbf{D}( p(x, y) \mid p(x) p(y) ) \ge 0 I(X;Y)=D(p(x,y)∣p(x)p(y))≥0

Or

∑p(x,y)log⁡p(x,y)p(x)p(y)=−∑p(x,y)log⁡p(x)p(y)p(x,y)≥−log⁡∑p(x,y)p(x)p(y)p(x,y)=0\begin{aligned} \sum p(x, y) \log \frac{ p(x, y)}{p(x) p(y) } &= -\sum p(x, y) \log \frac{p(x) p(y) }{ p(x, y)} \\ &\ge - \log \sum p(x, y) \frac{p(x) p(y) }{ p(x, y)} \\ &=0 \end{aligned} ∑p(x,y)logp(x)p(y)p(x,y)​​=−∑p(x,y)logp(x,y)p(x)p(y)​≥−log∑p(x,y)p(x,y)p(x)p(y)​=0​

□\square□

Corollary. H(Y)−H(X∣Y)=H(X)−H(X∣Y)≥0\mathbf{H} ( Y ) - \mathbf{H} ( X \mid Y) = \mathbf{H} ( X ) - \mathbf{H} ( X \mid Y) \ge 0H(Y)−H(X∣Y)=H(X)−H(X∣Y)≥0.

Theorem. The entropy H(X)\mathbf{H}(X)H(X) is concave in the probability density p(x)p(x)p(x).

Proof.
Let λ1,λ2∈[0,1]\lambda_1, \lambda_2 \in [0, 1]λ1​,λ2​∈[0,1] such that λ1+λ2=1\lambda_1 + \lambda_2 = 1λ1​+λ2​=1.
Suppose that Z1,Z2Z_1, Z_2Z1​,Z2​ are random variables with density functions p1(z)p_1(z)p1​(z) and p2(z)p_2(z)p2​(z) respectively.
Define the random variable

Y={1,w.p λ1,2,w.p λ2, Y = \begin{cases} 1, &\text{w.p } \lambda_1,\\ 2, &\text{w.p } \lambda_2, \end{cases} Y={1,2,​w.p λ1​,w.p λ2​,​

and let X=ZYX = Z_YX=ZY​.

Then

H(X)=H(λ1p1+λ2p2) \mathbf{H}(X) = \mathbf{H}( \lambda_1 p_1 + \lambda_2 p_2) H(X)=H(λ1​p1​+λ2​p2​)

On the other hand,

H(X∣Y)=λ1H(p1)+λ2H(p2). \mathbf{H}(X \mid Y) = \lambda_1 \mathbf{H}( p_1 ) + \lambda_2 \mathbf{H}( p_2 ). H(X∣Y)=λ1​H(p1​)+λ2​H(p2​).

We finish the proof by observing that H(X)≥H(X∣Y)\mathbf{H}(X) \ge \mathbf{H}(X \mid Y)H(X)≥H(X∣Y).

□\square□

Definition. Let XXX be a Bernoulli random variable with mean p∈[0,1]p \in [0, 1]p∈[0,1]. Denote H(p)=H(X)=plog⁡1p+(1−p)log⁡11−p\mathbf{H}(p) = \mathbf{H}(X) = p \log \frac{1}{p} + (1 - p) \log \frac{1}{1 - p}H(p)=H(X)=plogp1​+(1−p)log1−p1​.
Corollary. H(p)\mathbf{H}(p)H(p) is concave in ppp.

Conditional Mutual Information

Definition. The conditional mutual information between XXX and YYY given Z=zZ = zZ=z is the mutual information between the random variables XXX and YYY in the joint ensemble Pr⁡(X,Y∣Z=z)\Pr (X, Y | Z = z)Pr(X,Y∣Z=z),

I(X;Y∣Z=z)=H(X∣Z=z)−H(X∣Y,Z=z) I(X ; Y \mid Z = z) = \mathbf{H}(X \mid Z = z) - \mathbf{H}(X \mid Y, Z = z) I(X;Y∣Z=z)=H(X∣Z=z)−H(X∣Y,Z=z)

Definition. The conditional mutual information between XXX and YYY given ZZZ is average over zzz of I(X;Y∣Z=z)I(X; Y \mid Z = z)I(X;Y∣Z=z),

I(X;Y∣Z)=H(X∣Z)−H(X∣Y,Z)=H(Y∣Z)−H(Y∣X,Z)=H(X∣Z)+H(Y∣Z)−H(X,Y∣Z)=EX,Y,Zlog⁡p(X,Y∣Z)p(X∣Z)⋅p(Y∣Z). \begin{aligned} I(X; Y \mid Z) &= \mathbf{H}(X \mid Z) - \mathbf{H}(X \mid Y, Z) \\ &= \mathbf{H}(Y \mid Z) - \mathbf{H}(Y \mid X, Z) \\ &= \mathbf{H}(X \mid Z) + \mathbf{H}(Y \mid Z) - \mathbf{H}(X, Y \mid Z) \\ &= \mathbb{E}_{X, Y, Z} \log \frac{ p(X, Y \mid Z )}{ p(X \mid Z) \cdot p(Y \mid Z)}. \end{aligned} I(X;Y∣Z)​=H(X∣Z)−H(X∣Y,Z)=H(Y∣Z)−H(Y∣X,Z)=H(X∣Z)+H(Y∣Z)−H(X,Y∣Z)=EX,Y,Z​logp(X∣Z)⋅p(Y∣Z)p(X,Y∣Z)​.​

Conditional Relative Entropy

Definition (Conditional Relative Entropy).

D(p(y∣x)∣∣q(y∣x))≐Ep(x,y)[log⁡p(Y∣X)q(Y∣X)]=∑x∑yp(y∣x)log⁡p(y∣x)q(y∣x)\begin{aligned} \mathbf{D}( p(y \mid x) || q(y \mid x) ) &\doteq \mathbb{E}_{p(x, y) } \left[ \log \frac{ p(Y \mid X) }{ q(Y \mid X) } \right]\\ &=\sum_{x} \sum_{ y } p(y \mid x) \log \frac{ p(y \mid x) }{ q(y \mid x) } \end{aligned} D(p(y∣x)∣∣q(y∣x))​≐Ep(x,y)​[logq(Y∣X)p(Y∣X)​]=x∑​y∑​p(y∣x)logq(y∣x)p(y∣x)​​

Lemma. Relative entropy D(p∣∣q)\mathbf{D}( p || q )D(p∣∣q) is convex in the pair (p,q)(p, q)(p,q): if there are two distribution pairs (p1,q1)(p_1, q_1)(p1​,q1​) and (p2,q2)(p_2, q_2)(p2​,q2​), then for α1,α2∈[0,1]\alpha_1, \alpha_2 \in [0, 1]α1​,α2​∈[0,1], s.t., α1+α2=1\alpha_1 + \alpha_2 = 1α1​+α2​=1, it holds that

D(α1p1+α2p2∣∣α1q1+α2q2)≤α1D(p1∣∣q1)+α2D(p2∣∣q2) \mathbf{D}( \alpha_1 p_1 + \alpha_2 p_2 || \alpha_1 q_1 + \alpha_2 q_2 ) \le \alpha_1 \mathbf{D}( p_1 || q_1 ) + \alpha_2 \mathbf{D}( p_2 || q_2 ) D(α1​p1​+α2​p2​∣∣α1​q1​+α2​q2​)≤α1​D(p1​∣∣q1​)+α2​D(p2​∣∣q2​)

Proof.
For any fix value xxx, let s(x)s(x)s(x) be a shorthand for α1p1(x)+α2p2(x)\alpha_1 p_1(x) + \alpha_2 p_2(x)α1​p1​(x)+α2​p2​(x).
It holds that

s(x)log⁡s(x)α1q1(x)+α2q2(x)=−s(x)log⁡α1q1(x)+α2q2(x)s(x)=−s(x)log⁡(α1p1(x)s(x)α1q1(x)α1p1(x)+α2p2(x)s(x)α2q2(x)α2p2(x))≤−α1p1(x)log⁡q1(x)p1(x)−α2p2(x)log⁡q2(x)p2(x) \small \begin{aligned} s(x) \log \frac{ s(x) }{ \alpha_1 q_1(x) + \alpha_2 q_2(x) } &=-s(x) \log \frac { \alpha_1 q_1(x) + \alpha_2 q_2(x) } { s(x) } \\ &= -s(x) \log \left( \frac { \alpha_1 p_1(x) } { s(x) } \frac { \alpha_1 q_1(x) } { \alpha_1 p_1(x) } + \frac { \alpha_2 p_2(x) } { s(x) } \frac { \alpha_2 q_2(x) } { \alpha_2 p_2(x) } \right) \\ &\le -\alpha_1 p_1(x) \log \frac { q_1(x) } { p_1(x) } - \alpha_2 p_2(x) \log \frac { q_2(x) } { p_2(x) } \end{aligned} s(x)logα1​q1​(x)+α2​q2​(x)s(x)​​=−s(x)logs(x)α1​q1​(x)+α2​q2​(x)​=−s(x)log(s(x)α1​p1​(x)​α1​p1​(x)α1​q1​(x)​+s(x)α2​p2​(x)​α2​p2​(x)α2​q2​(x)​)≤−α1​p1​(x)logp1​(x)q1​(x)​−α2​p2​(x)logp2​(x)q2​(x)​​

□\square□

Chain Rules

Chain Rule for Information Content

log⁡1p(x,y)=log⁡1p(x)+log⁡1p(y∣x)\log \frac{1}{ p(x, y) } = \log \frac{1}{p(x) } + \log \frac{1}{p(y | x) }logp(x,y)1​=logp(x)1​+logp(y∣x)1​.

Chain Rule for Entropy

Let X1,…,XnX_1, \ldots, X_nX1​,…,Xn​ be random variables whose density function is p(x1…,xn)p(x_1 \ldots, x_n)p(x1​…,xn​).

H(X1,…,Xn)=∑i=1nH(Xi∣X1,…,Xi−1)\mathbf{H}(X_1, \ldots, X_n) = \sum_{i = 1}^n \mathbf{H}(X_i \mid X_1, \ldots, X_{i - 1})H(X1​,…,Xn​)=∑i=1n​H(Xi​∣X1​,…,Xi−1​)

Proof.

H(X1,…,Xn)=∑x1…,xnp(x1…,xn)log⁡1∏i=1np(xi∣x1,…,xi−1)=∑x1…,xnp(x1…,xn)∑i=1nlog⁡1p(xi∣x1,…,xi−1)=∑i=1nH(Xi∣X1,…,Xi−1) \small \begin{aligned} \mathbf{H}(X_1, \ldots, X_n) &= \sum_{x_1 \ldots, x_n} p(x_1 \ldots, x_n) \log \frac{1}{\prod_{i = 1}^n p(x_i \mid x_1, \ldots, x_{i - 1}) } \\ &= \sum_{x_1 \ldots, x_n} p(x_1 \ldots, x_n) \sum_{i = 1}^n \log \frac{1}{ p(x_i \mid x_1, \ldots, x_{i - 1}) } \\ &=\sum_{i = 1}^n \mathbf{H}(X_i \mid X_1, \ldots, X_{i - 1}) \\ \end{aligned} H(X1​,…,Xn​)​=x1​…,xn​∑​p(x1​…,xn​)log∏i=1n​p(xi​∣x1​,…,xi−1​)1​=x1​…,xn​∑​p(x1​…,xn​)i=1∑n​logp(xi​∣x1​,…,xi−1​)1​=i=1∑n​H(Xi​∣X1​,…,Xi−1​)​

□\square□

Corollary.
H(X1,…,Xn)≤∑i=1nH(Xi). \mathbf{H} ( X_1, \ldots, X_n) \le \sum_{i = 1}^n \mathbf{H}(X_i). H(X1​,…,Xn​)≤∑i=1n​H(Xi​).

□\square□

Chain Rule for Mutual Information

I(Y;X1,…,Xn)=∑i=1nI(Y;Xi∣X1,…,Xi−1)\mathbf{I}(Y; X_1, \ldots, X_n) = \sum_{i = 1}^n \mathbf{I}( Y; X_i \mid X_1, \ldots, X_{i - 1})I(Y;X1​,…,Xn​)=∑i=1n​I(Y;Xi​∣X1​,…,Xi−1​)

Proof 1.

I(X1,…,Xn;Y)=H(X1,…,Xn)−H(X1,…,Xn∣Y)=∑i=1nH(Xi∣X1,…,Xi−1)−∑i=1nH(Xi∣X1,…,Xi−1,Y)=∑i=1nI(Xi;Y∣X1,…,Xi−1) \small \begin{aligned} \mathbf{I}(X_1, \ldots, X_n; Y) &= \mathbf{H}(X_1, \ldots, X_n) - \mathbf{H}(X_1, \ldots, X_n \mid Y) \\ &= \sum_{i = 1}^n \mathbf{H}(X_i \mid X_1, \ldots, X_{i - 1}) - \sum_{i = 1}^n \mathbf{H}(X_i \mid X_1, \ldots, X_{i - 1}, Y) \\ &= \sum_{i = 1}^n \mathbf{I}(X_i ; Y\mid X_1, \ldots, X_{i - 1}) \end{aligned} I(X1​,…,Xn​;Y)​=H(X1​,…,Xn​)−H(X1​,…,Xn​∣Y)=i=1∑n​H(Xi​∣X1​,…,Xi−1​)−i=1∑n​H(Xi​∣X1​,…,Xi−1​,Y)=i=1∑n​I(Xi​;Y∣X1​,…,Xi−1​)​

□\square□

Proof 2.

I(Y;X1,…,Xn)=D(p(x1,…,xn,y)∥p(x1,…,xn)p(y))=∑x1,…,xn,yp(x1,…,xn,y)log⁡p(x1,…,xn,y)p(x1,…,xn)p(y)=∑x1,…,xn,yp(x1,…,xn,y)(log⁡1p(x1,…,xn)−log⁡1p(x1,…,xn∣y))=∑x1,…,xn,yp(x1,…,xn,y)log⁡1p(x1)⋅p(x2∣x1)⋅…⋅p(xn∣x1,…,xn−1)−∑x1,…,xn,yp(x1,…,xn,y)log⁡1p(x1∣y)⋅p(x2∣x1,y)⋅…⋅p(xn∣x1,…,xn−1,y)=∑x1,…,xn,yp(x1,…,xn,y)(∑i∈[n]log⁡p(xi∣x1,…,xi−1,y)p(xi∣x1,…,xi−1))=∑i=1nI(Y;Xi∣X1,…,Xi−1) \small \begin{aligned} \mathbf{I}( Y ; X_1, \ldots, X_n ) &= \mathbf{D} ( p(x_1, \ldots, x_n, y) \Vert p(x_1, \ldots, x_n) p(y)) \\ &= \sum_{x_1, \ldots, x_n, y } p(x_1, \ldots, x_n, y) \log \frac{ p( x_1, \ldots, x_n, y) }{ p( x_1, \ldots, x_n ) p(y) } \\ &= \sum_{x_1, \ldots, x_n, y } p(x_1, \ldots, x_n, y) \left( \log \frac{1}{ p(x_1, \ldots, x_n) } - \log \frac{1}{ p(x_1, \ldots, x_n \mid y ) } \right) \\ &= \sum_{x_1, \ldots, x_n, y } p(x_1, \ldots, x_n, y) \log \frac{1}{ p(x_1) \cdot p(x_2 \mid x_1) \cdot \ldots \cdot p(x_n \mid x_1, \ldots, x_{n - 1} ) } \\ & - \sum_{x_1, \ldots, x_n, y } p(x_1, \ldots, x_n, y) \log \frac{1}{ p(x_1 \mid y) \cdot p(x_2 \mid x_1, y) \cdot \ldots \cdot p(x_n \mid x_1, \ldots, x_{n - 1}, y ) } \\ &= \sum_{x_1, \ldots, x_n, y } p(x_1, \ldots, x_n, y) \left( \sum_{i \in [n] } \log \frac{ p(x_i \mid x_1, \ldots, x_{i - 1}, y) }{ p(x_i \mid x_1, \ldots, x_{i - 1}) } \right) \\ &= \sum_{i = 1}^n \mathbf{I}( Y ; X_i \mid X_1, \ldots, X_{i - 1}) \end{aligned} I(Y;X1​,…,Xn​)​=D(p(x1​,…,xn​,y)∥p(x1​,…,xn​)p(y))=x1​,…,xn​,y∑​p(x1​,…,xn​,y)logp(x1​,…,xn​)p(y)p(x1​,…,xn​,y)​=x1​,…,xn​,y∑​p(x1​,…,xn​,y)(logp(x1​,…,xn​)1​−logp(x1​,…,xn​∣y)1​)=x1​,…,xn​,y∑​p(x1​,…,xn​,y)logp(x1​)⋅p(x2​∣x1​)⋅…⋅p(xn​∣x1​,…,xn−1​)1​−x1​,…,xn​,y∑​p(x1​,…,xn​,y)logp(x1​∣y)⋅p(x2​∣x1​,y)⋅…⋅p(xn​∣x1​,…,xn−1​,y)1​=x1​,…,xn​,y∑​p(x1​,…,xn​,y)(i∈[n]∑​logp(xi​∣x1​,…,xi−1​)p(xi​∣x1​,…,xi−1​,y)​)=i=1∑n​I(Y;Xi​∣X1​,…,Xi−1​)​

□\square□

Convexity of Relative Entropy.

D(p(x,y)∣∣q(x,y))=D(p(x)∣∣q(x))+D(p(y∣x)∣∣q(y∣x)). \mathbf{D}( p(x, y) || q(x, y) ) = \mathbf{D}( p(x) || q(x) ) + \mathbf{D}( p(y \mid x) || q(y \mid x) ). D(p(x,y)∣∣q(x,y))=D(p(x)∣∣q(x))+D(p(y∣x)∣∣q(y∣x)).

Proof.

D(p(x,y)∣∣q(x,y))=∑x,yp(x,y)log⁡p(x)p(y∣x)q(x)q(y∣x)=∑x,yp(x,y)log⁡p(x)q(x)+∑x,yp(x,y)log⁡p(y∣x)q(y∣x)=D(p(x)∣∣q(x))+D(p(y∣x)∣∣q(y∣x))\begin{aligned} \mathbf{D}( p(x, y) || q(x, y) ) &= \sum_{x, y} p(x, y) \log \frac{ p(x) p(y \mid x) }{q(x) q (y \mid x) } \\ &= \sum_{x, y} p(x, y) \log \frac{ p(x) }{q(x) } + \sum_{x, y} p(x, y) \log \frac{ p(y \mid x) }{ q (y \mid x) } \\ &= \mathbf{D}( p(x) || q(x) ) + \mathbf{D}( p(y \mid x) || q(y \mid x) ) \end{aligned} D(p(x,y)∣∣q(x,y))​=x,y∑​p(x,y)logq(x)q(y∣x)p(x)p(y∣x)​=x,y∑​p(x,y)logq(x)p(x)​+x,y∑​p(x,y)logq(y∣x)p(y∣x)​=D(p(x)∣∣q(x))+D(p(y∣x)∣∣q(y∣x))​

□\square□

Amplificatoin by Sampling

Posted on 2021-07-05

Definition. Two distribution μ\muμ and μ′\mu'μ′ are (ϵ,δ)(\epsilon, \delta)(ϵ,δ) close, denoted as μ≃(ϵ,δ)μ′\mu \simeq_{(\epsilon, \delta) } \mu'μ≃(ϵ,δ)​μ′, if for all measurable set AAA, we have

μ(A)≤eϵμ′(A)+δ,μ′(A)≤eϵμ(A)+δ. \begin{aligned} \mu(A) &\le e^\epsilon \mu'(A) + \delta, \\ \mu'(A) &\le e^\epsilon \mu(A) + \delta. \end{aligned} μ(A)μ′(A)​≤eϵμ′(A)+δ,≤eϵμ(A)+δ.​

Theorem. Let q∈(0,1)q \in (0, 1)q∈(0,1) and let μ\muμ and μ′\mu'μ′ be two distributions such that μ≃(ϵ,δ)μ′\mu \simeq_{(\epsilon, \delta)} \mu'μ≃(ϵ,δ)​μ′. For ν=(1−q)μ+qμ′\nu = (1 - q) \mu + q \mu'ν=(1−q)μ+qμ′, it holds that

ν≃(ϵ′,qδ)μ, \nu \simeq_{ (\epsilon', q \delta) } \mu, ν≃(ϵ′,qδ)​μ,

where ϵ′=ln⁡(q(eϵ−1)+1)\epsilon' = \ln ( q (e^\epsilon - 1) + 1 )ϵ′=ln(q(eϵ−1)+1).

Proof. For each measurable set AAA

ν(A)=(1−q)μ(A)+qμ′(A)≤(1−q)μ(A)+q(eϵμ(A)+δ)=(q(eϵ−1)+1)μ(A)+qδ. \begin{aligned} \nu(A) &= (1 - q) \mu(A) + q \mu' (A) \\ &\le (1 - q) \mu(A) + q (e^\epsilon \mu (A) + \delta) \\ &= ( q (e^\epsilon - 1) + 1 ) \mu(A) + q \delta. \end{aligned} ν(A)​=(1−q)μ(A)+qμ′(A)≤(1−q)μ(A)+q(eϵμ(A)+δ)=(q(eϵ−1)+1)μ(A)+qδ.​

Next we prove the other direction.
Denote t=eϵ−1t = e^{\epsilon} - 1t=eϵ−1.
Then

eϵ′=1+qt, e^{\epsilon'} = 1 + qt, eϵ′=1+qt,

and

ν(A)=(1−q)μ(A)+qμ′(A)≥(1−q)μ(A)+qe−ϵ(μ(A)−δ)=(1−q)μ(A)+q1+t(μ(A)−δ)=μ(A)−qt1+tμ(A)−q1+tδ=(1−qt1+t)μ(A)−11+tqδ≥(1−qt1+qt)μ(A)−11+qtqδ=11+qt(μ(A)−qδ). \begin{aligned} \nu(A) &= (1 - q) \mu(A) + q \mu' (A) \\ &\ge (1 - q) \mu(A) + q e^{-\epsilon} (\mu (A) - \delta) \\ &= (1 - q) \mu(A) + \frac{q}{1 + t} (\mu (A) - \delta) \\ &= \mu(A) - \frac{qt}{1 + t} \mu (A) - \frac{q}{1 + t} \delta \\ &= \left( 1 - \frac{qt}{1 + t} \right) \mu (A) - \frac{1}{1 + t} q \delta \\ &\ge \left( 1 - \frac{qt}{1 + qt} \right) \mu (A) - \frac{1}{1 + qt} q \delta \\ &= \frac{1}{1 + qt} \left( \mu (A) - q \delta \right). \end{aligned} ν(A)​=(1−q)μ(A)+qμ′(A)≥(1−q)μ(A)+qe−ϵ(μ(A)−δ)=(1−q)μ(A)+1+tq​(μ(A)−δ)=μ(A)−1+tqt​μ(A)−1+tq​δ=(1−1+tqt​)μ(A)−1+t1​qδ≥(1−1+qtqt​)μ(A)−1+qt1​qδ=1+qt1​(μ(A)−qδ).​

□\square□

Reference

[1] Ú. Erlingsson, V. Feldman, I. Mironov, A. Raghunathan, K. Talwar, and A. Thakurta, “Amplification by Shuffling: From Local to Central Differential Privacy via Anonymity,”

Fubini's Theorem

Posted on 2021-06-28 Edited on 2024-03-12

Let (X,F1,μ1)(X, \mathcal{F}_1, \mu_1)(X,F1​,μ1​)
and (Y,F2,μ2)(Y, \mathcal{F}_2, \mu_2)(Y,F2​,μ2​)
be two σ\sigmaσ-finite measure space.

Produce Measure Space

Consider the product space Ω=X×Y\Omega = X \times YΩ=X×Y.

Definition. A measurable rectangle is a product A×BA \times BA×B for which A∈F1A \in \mathcal{F}_1A∈F1​ and B∈F2B \in \mathcal{F}_2B∈F2​.

Denote the collection of measurable rectangles as

S≐{A×B,A∈F1,B∈F2}. \mathcal{S} \doteq \begin{Bmatrix} A \times B, A \in \mathcal{F}_1, B \in \mathcal{F}_2 \end{Bmatrix}. S≐{A×B,A∈F1​,B∈F2​​}.

We would like to construct a measure μ\muμ on σ(S)\sigma(\mathcal{S})σ(S), the σ\sigmaσ-field generated by S\mathcal{S}S, thus

  1. For each A×B∈SA \times B \in \mathcal{S}A×B∈S, it’s natural to define μ(A×B)=μ1(A)⋅μ2(B)\mu (A \times B) = \mu_1(A) \cdot \mu_2(B)μ(A×B)=μ1​(A)⋅μ2​(B).

  2. We prove that S\mathcal{S}S is a semialgebra.

  3. We show that μ\muμ is a measure on S\mathcal{S}S.

  4. Finally, it follows by the Caratheodory’s Extension Theorem, μ\muμ has a unique extension on σ(S)\sigma(\mathcal{S})σ(S).

Lemma 1. S\mathcal{S}S is a semialgebra.

Proof.

  • S\mathcal{S}S is close under intersection: if A×B,C×D∈SA \times B, C \times D \in \mathcal{S}A×B,C×D∈S, then

    (A×B)∩(C×D)=(A∩C)×(B∩D). (A \times B) \cap (C \times D) = (A \cap C) \times (B \cap D). (A×B)∩(C×D)=(A∩C)×(B∩D).

  • The complement of element in S\mathcal{S}S is a finite disjoint union of elements in S\mathcal{S}S: if A×B∈SA \times B \in \mathcal{S}A×B∈S, since

    Ω=(A×B)+(Aˉ×B)+(A×Bˉ)+(Aˉ×Bˉ), \Omega = (A \times B) + ( \bar A \times B ) + ( A \times \bar B ) + ( \bar A \times \bar B ), Ω=(A×B)+(Aˉ×B)+(A×Bˉ)+(Aˉ×Bˉ),

    it holds that

    A×B‾=(Aˉ×B)+(A×Bˉ)+(Aˉ×Bˉ). \overline{ A \times B } = ( \bar A \times B ) + ( A \times \bar B ) + ( \bar A \times \bar B ). A×B​=(Aˉ×B)+(A×Bˉ)+(Aˉ×Bˉ).

□\square□

Lemma 2. μ\muμ is a measure on S\mathcal{S}S.

Proof. It suffices to prove σ\sigmaσ-additivity of μ\muμ.
Suppose A×B=+i≥1(Ai×Bi)A \times B = +_{i \ge 1} (A_i \times B_i)A×B=+i≥1​(Ai​×Bi​) is a countable disjoint union of elements in S\mathcal{S}S.

Fix an x∈Ax \in Ax∈A.
For each y∈By \in By∈B, we have (x,y)∈A×B(x, y) \in A \times B(x,y)∈A×B.
As the sets {Ai×Bi}\begin{Bmatrix} A_i \times B_i \end{Bmatrix}{Ai​×Bi​​} consists of a partition of A×BA \times BA×B, it follows that (x,y)(x, y)(x,y) belongs to exactly one Ai×BiA_i \times B_iAi​×Bi​.
Denote

I(x)≐{i:∃y∈B, s.t., (x,y)∈Ai×Bi}={i:x∈Ai}. I(x) \doteq \begin{Bmatrix} i : \exists y \in B,\, \text{s.t.},\, (x, y) \in A_i \times B_i \end{Bmatrix} = \begin{Bmatrix} i : x \in A_i \end{Bmatrix}. I(x)≐{i:∃y∈B,s.t.,(x,y)∈Ai​×Bi​​}={i:x∈Ai​​}.

Then B=+i∈I(x)BiB = +_{i \in I(x) } B_iB=+i∈I(x)​Bi​.

As μ2\mu_2μ2​ is a measure on YYY, it is countably additive:

μ2(B)=∑i∈I(x)μ(Bi)  ⟹  IA(x)μ2(B)=∑i≥1IAi(x)⋅μ2(B). \mu_2 (B) = \sum_{i \in I(x) } \mu(B_i ) \implies \mathbb{I}_A (x) \mu_2(B) = \sum_{i \ge 1} \mathbb{I}_{ A_i } (x) \cdot \mu_2 (B). μ2​(B)=i∈I(x)∑​μ(Bi​)⟹IA​(x)μ2​(B)=i≥1∑​IAi​​(x)⋅μ2​(B).

By monotone convergence theorem,

∫XIA(x)μ2(B) d μ1=∑i≥1∫XIAi(x)⋅μ2(B)d μ1, \int_X \mathbb{I}_A(x) \mu_2(B) \, d\, \mu_1 = \sum_{i \ge 1} \int_X \mathbb{I}_{ A_i } (x) \cdot \mu_2 (B) d\, \mu_1, ∫X​IA​(x)μ2​(B)dμ1​=i≥1∑​∫X​IAi​​(x)⋅μ2​(B)dμ1​,

which is

μ1(A)⋅μ2(B)=∑i≥1μ1(Ai)⋅μ2(Bi). \mu_1 (A) \cdot \mu_2 (B) = \sum_{i \ge 1} \mu_1 (A_i) \cdot \mu_2 (B_i). μ1​(A)⋅μ2​(B)=i≥1∑​μ1​(Ai​)⋅μ2​(Bi​).

□\square□

Theorem. μ\muμ has a unique extension μˉ\bar \muμˉ​ on σ(S)\sigma( \mathcal{S} )σ(S), the σ\sigmaσ-field generated by S\mathcal{S}S.

Proof. Note that S\mathcal{S}S is a semialgebra and μ\muμ is a σ\sigmaσ-finite measure.
Applying
Caratheodory’s Extension Theorem
directly finishes the proof.

□\square□

Fubini’s Theorem

Let {ai:i∈N}\begin{Bmatrix} a_i : i \in \mathbb{N} \end{Bmatrix}{ai​:i∈N​} be a countably sequence of numbers.
Then the series converges to the same limit under permutation, if

  1. ai≥0,∀i∈Na_i \ge 0, \forall i \in \mathbb{N}ai​≥0,∀i∈N. Note that ∑i≥1ai\sum_{i \ge 1} a_i∑i≥1​ai​ can equal ∞\infty∞.

  2. ∑i≥1∣ai∣<∞\sum_{i \ge 1} | a_i | < \infty∑i≥1​∣ai​∣<∞.

Integration is a generalization of discrete sum.
Given a measure space (Ω,σ(S),μˉ)(\Omega, \sigma( \mathcal{S} ), \bar \mu)(Ω,σ(S),μˉ​), and a measure function fff, the integral of fff exists, if

  1. f≥0f \ge 0f≥0;
  2. Or ∫∣f∣d μˉ<∞\int |f| d\, \bar \mu < \infty∫∣f∣dμˉ​<∞.

In case that (Ω,σ(S),μˉ)(\Omega, \sigma( \mathcal{S} ), \bar \mu)(Ω,σ(S),μˉ​) is a produce measure space, the Fubini’s theorem states that if the double integral exists, it can be computed by iterated integrals.

Theorem (Fubini’s Theorem). If f≥0f \ge 0f≥0 or ∫∣f∣d μˉ<∞\int |f| d\, \bar \mu < \infty∫∣f∣dμˉ​<∞, then there exists A∈F1A \in \mathcal{F}_1A∈F1​, B∈F2B \in \mathcal{F}_2B∈F2​, s.t., μ1(A)=μ2(B)=0\mu_1 (A) = \mu_2 (B) = 0μ1​(A)=μ2​(B)=0, and

∫X−A∫Yf(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∫Ωf(x,y)d μˉ=∫Y−B∫Xf(x,y)d μ1 d μ2. \int_{X - A} \int_Y f(x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 = \int_{\Omega } f(x, y) d\, \bar \mu = \int_{Y - B} \int_X f(x, y) d\, \mu_1 \, d\, \mu_2. ∫X−A​∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=∫Ω​f(x,y)dμˉ​=∫Y−B​∫X​f(x,y)dμ1​dμ2​.

Remark. For the case concerning f≥0f \ge 0f≥0, we have A=B=∅A = B = \emptysetA=B=∅, and the Theorem is called Tonelli’s theorem.

Comparison with Discrete Sum

Let X=Y=NX = Y = \mathbb{N}X=Y=N, and μ1=μ2\mu_1 = \mu_2μ1​=μ2​ be counting measures.
Let {ai,j:i,j∈N}\begin{Bmatrix} a_{i,j} : i, j \in \mathbb{N} \end{Bmatrix}{ai,j​:i,j∈N​} be a sequency of numbers and define f(i,j)=ai,jf(i, j) = a_{i,j}f(i,j)=ai,j​.
Denote

E1≐{(i,j)∈N×N:ai,j≥0},E2≐{(i,j)∈N×N:ai,j<0}. E_1 \doteq \begin{Bmatrix} (i, j) \in \mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N} : a_{i,j} \ge 0 \end{Bmatrix}, \\ E_2 \doteq \begin{Bmatrix} (i, j) \in \mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N} : a_{i,j} < 0 \end{Bmatrix}. E1​≐{(i,j)∈N×N:ai,j​≥0​},E2​≐{(i,j)∈N×N:ai,j​<0​}.

By definition of integration,
∫Ωf(x,y) d μˉ\int_\Omega f(x, y) \, d\, \bar \mu∫Ω​f(x,y)dμˉ​ exists if

  1. Either f≥0f \ge 0f≥0. In this case

    ∫Ωf(x,y) d μˉ=sup⁡{∑(i,j)∈Sai,j:S⊆N×N∣S∣<∞}, \int_\Omega f(x, y) \, d\, \bar \mu = \sup \begin{Bmatrix} \sum_{ ( i,j ) \in S } a_{i,j} : \begin{array}{l} S \subseteq \mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N} \\ |S| < \infty \end{array} \end{Bmatrix}, ∫Ω​f(x,y)dμˉ​=sup{∑(i,j)∈S​ai,j​:S⊆N×N∣S∣<∞​​},

  2. Or ∫Ω∣f(x,y)∣ d μˉ<∞\int_\Omega | f(x, y) | \, d\, \bar \mu < \infty∫Ω​∣f(x,y)∣dμˉ​<∞. In this case,

    ∫Ωf(x,y) d μˉ=∫Ωf+ d μˉ−∫Ωf− d μˉ=sup⁡{∑(i,j)∈Sai,j: S⊆E1∣S∣<∞}−sup⁡{∑(i,j)∈Sai,j: S⊆E2∣S∣<∞}. \begin{aligned} &\int_\Omega f(x, y) \, d\, \bar \mu = \int_\Omega f_+ \, d\, \bar \mu - \int_\Omega f_- \, d\, \bar \mu \\ &= \sup \begin{Bmatrix} \sum_{ ( i,j ) \in S } a_{i,j}: \, \begin{matrix} S \subseteq E_1 \\ |S| < \infty \end{matrix} \end{Bmatrix} - \sup \begin{Bmatrix} \sum_{ ( i,j ) \in S } a_{i,j}: \, \begin{matrix} S \subseteq E_2 \\ |S| < \infty \end{matrix} \end{Bmatrix} . \end{aligned} ​∫Ω​f(x,y)dμˉ​=∫Ω​f+​dμˉ​−∫Ω​f−​dμˉ​=sup{∑(i,j)∈S​ai,j​:S⊆E1​∣S∣<∞​​}−sup{∑(i,j)∈S​ai,j​:S⊆E2​∣S∣<∞​​}.​

In the former case, the summation of elements in a chosen set SSS grows in one direction. While in the later, the summation converges absolutely.

When ∫Ωf(x,y) d μˉ\int_\Omega f(x, y) \, d\, \bar \mu∫Ω​f(x,y)dμˉ​ exists, the following iterated integrals exist:

∫X∫Yf(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∑i≥1∑j≥1ai,j,∫Y∫Xf(x,y)d μ1 d μ2=∑j≥1∑i≥1ai,j. \int_X \int_Y f(x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 = \sum_{i \ge 1} \sum_{j \ge 1} a_{i,j}, \\ \int_Y \int_X f(x, y) d\, \mu_1 \, d\, \mu_2 = \sum_{j \ge 1} \sum_{i \ge 1} a_{i,j}. ∫X​∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=i≥1∑​j≥1∑​ai,j​,∫Y​∫X​f(x,y)dμ1​dμ2​=j≥1∑​i≥1∑​ai,j​.

Further, their values are equal.

□\square□

Proof of Fubini’s Theorem

By symmetry, it suffices to prove that

∫X∫Yf(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∫Ωf(x,y)d μˉ. \int_X \int_Y f(x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 = \int_{\Omega } f(x, y) d\, \bar \mu. ∫X​∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=∫Ω​f(x,y)dμˉ​.

Sketch of the Proof

Before proving that the iterated integral equals the double integral, we need to make sure that the first iterated integral is well-defined.
Specifically,

  • When xxx is fixed, the function fx:Y→Rf_x : Y \rightarrow \mathbb{R}fx​:Y→R defined by fx(y)≐f(x,y)f_x(y) \doteq f(x, y)fx​(y)≐f(x,y) is F2\mathcal{F}_2F2​ measurable, and the integral ∫Yf(x,y) d μ2\int_Y f(x, y) \, d\, \mu_2∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​ exists.

  • There is F1\mathcal{F}_1F1​ measurable function g:X→Rg : X \rightarrow \mathbb{R}g:X→R such that g(x)=∫Yf(x,y) d μ2g(x) = \int_Y f(x, y) \, d\, \mu_2g(x)=∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​ almost everywhere.

We will first establish the theorem for indicator functions IE\mathbb{I}_EIE​ for sets E∈σ(S)E \in \sigma( \mathcal{S} )E∈σ(S), which serve as basic building blocks for extending the theorem for more general functions.

Lemma. Given E∈σ(S)E \in \sigma( \mathcal{S} )E∈σ(S), let IE\mathbb{I}_EIE​ be the indicator for (x,y)∈E(x, y) \in E(x,y)∈E. Then

  1. For each x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, the function fx(y)≐IE(x,y)f_x(y) \doteq \mathbb{I}_E (x, y)fx​(y)≐IE​(x,y) is F2\mathcal{F}_2F2​ measurable.

  2. The function g(x)≐∫YIE(x,y)d μ2g(x) \doteq \int_Y \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \mu_2g(x)≐∫Y​IE​(x,y)dμ2​ is F1\mathcal{F}_1F1​ measurable.

  3. ∫X∫YIE(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∫ΩIE(x,y)d μˉ. \int_X \int_Y \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 = \int_{\Omega } \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \bar \mu. ∫X​∫Y​IE​(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=∫Ω​IE​(x,y)dμˉ​.

The proof of the lemma is deferred to the end of the article.

Proof of the Theorem

For now, we apply it to prove Theorem for the following three increasingly more general cases.

Case One. fff is a simple function on (X×Y,σ(S))(X \times Y, \sigma(\mathcal{S}))(X×Y,σ(S)).

Case Two. f≥0f \ge 0f≥0 and is σ(S)\sigma(\mathcal{S})σ(S) measurable.

Case Three. fff is measurable and integrable.

Remark: this follows exactly the same order with which we define Lebesgue integrals.

Proof of the Lemma

Lemma. Given E∈σ(S)E \in \sigma( \mathcal{S} )E∈σ(S), let IE\mathbb{I}_EIE​ be the indicator for (x,y)∈E(x, y) \in E(x,y)∈E. Then

  1. For each x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, the function fx(y)≐IE(x,y)f_x(y) \doteq \mathbb{I}_E (x, y)fx​(y)≐IE​(x,y) is F2\mathcal{F}_2F2​ measurable.

  2. The function g(x)≐∫YIE(x,y)d μ2g(x) \doteq \int_Y \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \mu_2g(x)≐∫Y​IE​(x,y)dμ2​ is F1\mathcal{F}_1F1​ measurable.

  3. ∫X∫YIE(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∫ΩIE(x,y)d μˉ. \int_X \int_Y \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 = \int_{\Omega } \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \bar \mu. ∫X​∫Y​IE​(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=∫Ω​IE​(x,y)dμˉ​.

There are various ways to prove this lemma.
We present two proofs here.

Proof One

Since XXX and YYY are both σ\sigmaσ-finite, there exists Ak∈F1,μ1(Ak)<∞,∀n∈N+A_k \in \mathcal{F}_1, \mu_1(A_k) < \infty, \forall n \in \mathbb{N}^+Ak​∈F1​,μ1​(Ak​)<∞,∀n∈N+, s.t., Ak↑XA_k \uparrow XAk​↑X, and Bk∈F2,μ2(Bk)<∞,∀n∈N+B_k \in \mathcal{F}_2, \mu_2(B_k) < \infty, \forall n \in \mathbb{N}^+Bk​∈F2​,μ2​(Bk​)<∞,∀n∈N+, s.t., Bk↑YB_k \uparrow YBk​↑Y.
It follows that Ωk≐Ak×Bk↑Ω\Omega_k \doteq A_k \times B_k \uparrow \OmegaΩk​≐Ak​×Bk​↑Ω, and that μ(Ωk)<∞\mu(\Omega_k) < \inftyμ(Ωk​)<∞.

Define

Lk≐{E∈σ(S):E∩Ωk  satisfies the conditions in the Lemma }. \mathcal{L}_k \doteq \{ E \in \sigma(\mathcal{S}) : E \cap \Omega_k \, \text{ satisfies the conditions in the Lemma } \}. Lk​≐{E∈σ(S):E∩Ωk​ satisfies the conditions in the Lemma }.

Claim. If Lk=σ(S)\mathcal{L}_k = \sigma(\mathcal{S})Lk​=σ(S),
then the lemma holds.

Proof of the Claim.
For each E∈σ(S)E \in \sigma(\mathcal{S})E∈σ(S),

  2. Let g(k)(x)≐∫YIE∩Ωk(x,y)d μ2g^{(k)} (x) \doteq \int_Y \mathbb{I}_{E \cap \Omega_k} (x, y) d\, \mu_2g(k)(x)≐∫Y​IE∩Ωk​​(x,y)dμ2​ are increasing.
    Since 0≤fx(n)(y)↑fx(y)0 \le f_x^{ (n) } (y) \uparrow f_x(y)0≤fx(n)​(y)↑fx​(y), by monotone convergence theorem: by monotone convergence theorem:

    g(x)=∫Yfx(y)d μ2=lim⁡k∫YIE∩Ωk(x,y)d μ2=lim⁡kg(k)(x) g(x) = \int_Y f_x(y) d\, \mu_2 = \lim_k \int_Y \mathbb{I}_{E \cap \Omega_k} (x, y) d\, \mu_2 = \lim_k g^{(k)} (x) g(x)=∫Y​fx​(y)dμ2​=klim​∫Y​IE∩Ωk​​(x,y)dμ2​=klim​g(k)(x)

□\square□

It is left to prove that Lk=σ(S)\mathcal{L}_k = \sigma(\mathcal{S})Lk​=σ(S).
The proof relies on the following fact.

Fact. If S~\tilde{S}S~ is an algebra, then the monotone class M(S~)\mathcal{M}(\tilde{S})M(S~) generated by S~\tilde{S}S~ equals σ(S~)\sigma(\tilde{S})σ(S~).

The proof consists of two steps:

  • Lk\mathcal{L}_kLk​ contains the algebra S~\tilde{S}S~ generated by SSS.

  • Lk\mathcal{L}_kLk​ is a monotone class.

In what follows, to ease the notations, we write Lk\mathcal{L}_kLk​ as L\mathcal{L}L and assume that μ(Ω)<∞\mu(\Omega) < \inftyμ(Ω)<∞.

L\mathcal{L}L contains the algebra S~\tilde{S}S~ generated by SSS.

Let E=+i(Ai×Bi)E = +_i \big( A_i \times B_i \big)E=+i​(Ai​×Bi​) for a finite sequence of disjoint rectangles Ai×BiA_i \times B_iAi​×Bi​.

  1. For each x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, the function fx(y)≐IE(x,y)f_x(y) \doteq \mathbb{I}_E (x, y)fx​(y)≐IE​(x,y) is a simple function on YYY and there F2\mathcal{F}_2F2​ measurable.

  2. The function

    g(x)=∫YIE(x,y)d μ2=∑iIAi(x)⋅μ2(Bi) g(x) = \int_Y \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \mu_2 = \sum_i \mathbb{I}_{A_i} (x) \cdot \mu_2(B_i) g(x)=∫Y​IE​(x,y)dμ2​=i∑​IAi​​(x)⋅μ2​(Bi​)

    is a simple function on XXX and there F1\mathcal{F}_1F1​ measurable.

∫Xg(x) d μ1=μ1(A)⋅μ2(B)=μˉ(E)=∫ΩIE(x,y)d μˉ. \int_X g(x) \, d\, \mu_1 = \mu_1 (A) \cdot \mu_2 (B) = \bar \mu (E) = \int_{\Omega } \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \bar \mu. ∫X​g(x)dμ1​=μ1​(A)⋅μ2​(B)=μˉ​(E)=∫Ω​IE​(x,y)dμˉ​.

L\mathcal{L}L is a monotone class.

Case One En∈L,n∈N+E_n \in \mathcal{L}, n \in \mathbb{N}^+En​∈L,n∈N+, s.t., En↑EE_n \uparrow EEn​↑E

  1. For each x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, we have fx(n)(y)=IEn(x,y)↑fx(y)f_x^{ (n) } (y) = \mathbb{I}_{E_n} (x, y) \uparrow f_x(y)fx(n)​(y)=IEn​​(x,y)↑fx​(y).
    Since the fx(n)(y)f_x^{ (n) } (y)fx(n)​(y) F2\mathcal{F}_2F2​ measurable, so is the function fx(y)f_x(y)fx​(y).

  2. Let g(n)(x)≐∫Yf(n)(x,y)d μ2g^{(n)} (x) \doteq \int_Y f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \mu_2g(n)(x)≐∫Y​f(n)(x,y)dμ2​.
    Since 0≤fx(n)(y)↑fx(y)0 \le f_x^{ (n) } (y) \uparrow f_x(y)0≤fx(n)​(y)↑fx​(y), by monotone convergence theorem:

    g(x)=∫Yfx(y)d μ2=lim⁡n∫Yfx(n)(y)d μ2=lim⁡ng(n)(x) g(x) = \int_Y f_x(y) d\, \mu_2 = \lim_n \int_Y f_x^{ (n) } (y) d\, \mu_2 = \lim_n g^{(n)} (x) g(x)=∫Y​fx​(y)dμ2​=nlim​∫Y​fx(n)​(y)dμ2​=nlim​g(n)(x)

    It follows that g(n)(x)↑g(x)g^{(n)} (x) \uparrow g(x)g(n)(x)↑g(x).
    Since they are F1\mathcal{F}_1F1​ measurable, so is g(x)g(x)g(x).

  3. Since ∫Yf(n)(x,y)d μ2↑∫Yf(x,y)d μ2 \int_Y f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \uparrow \int_Y f(x, y) d\, \mu_2 \,∫Y​f(n)(x,y)dμ2​↑∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​, ∫X∫Yf(n)(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∫Ωf(n)(x,y)d μˉ \int_X \int_Y f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 = \int_{\Omega } f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \bar \mu \,∫X​∫Y​f(n)(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=∫Ω​f(n)(x,y)dμˉ​, and f(n)(x,y)↑f(x,y)f^{(n)} (x, y) \uparrow f(x, y)f(n)(x,y)↑f(x,y), by monotone convergence theorem,

∫X∫Yf(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=lim⁡n∫X∫Yf(n)(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=lim⁡n∫Ωf(n)(x,y)d μˉ=∫Ωlim⁡nf(n)(x,y)d μˉ=∫Ωf(x,y)d μˉ. \begin{aligned} \int_X \int_Y f(x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 &= \lim_n \int_X \int_Y f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 \\ &= \lim_n \int_{\Omega } f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \bar \mu \\ &= \int_{\Omega } \lim_n f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \bar \mu \\ &= \int_{\Omega } f (x, y) d\, \bar \mu. \end{aligned} ∫X​∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​​=nlim​∫X​∫Y​f(n)(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=nlim​∫Ω​f(n)(x,y)dμˉ​=∫Ω​nlim​f(n)(x,y)dμˉ​=∫Ω​f(x,y)dμˉ​.​

Case Two En∈L,n∈N+E_n \in \mathcal{L}, n \in \mathbb{N}^+En​∈L,n∈N+, s.t., En↓EE_n \downarrow EEn​↓E

  1. For each x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, we have fx(n)(y)=IEn(x,y)↓fx(y)f_x^{ (n) } (y) = \mathbb{I}_{E_n} (x, y) \downarrow f_x(y)fx(n)​(y)=IEn​​(x,y)↓fx​(y).
    Since the fx(n)(y)f_x^{ (n) } (y)fx(n)​(y) are F2\mathcal{F}_2F2​ measurable, so is the function fx(y)f_x(y)fx​(y).

  2. Since fx(n)(y)=IEn(x,y)↓fx(y)f_x^{ (n) } (y) = \mathbb{I}_{E_n} (x, y) \downarrow f_x(y)fx(n)​(y)=IEn​​(x,y)↓fx​(y) and fx(n)(y)≤1f_x^{ (n) } (y) \le 1fx(n)​(y)≤1, 0≤1−fx(n)(y)↑1−fx(y)0 \le 1 - f_x^{ (n) } (y) \uparrow 1 - f_x(y)0≤1−fx(n)​(y)↑1−fx​(y).
    By monotone convergence theorem:

    μ2(Y)−lim⁡ng(n)(x)=lim⁡n∫Y(1−fx(n)(y))d μ2=∫Y(1−fx(y))d μ2=μ2(Y)−g(x). \begin{aligned} \mu_2(Y) - \lim_n g^{(n)} (x) &= \lim_n \int_Y \left( 1 - f_x^{ (n) } (y) \right) d\, \mu_2 \\ &= \int_Y \left( 1 - f_x(y) \right) d\, \mu_2 \\ &= \mu_2(Y) - g(x). \end{aligned} μ2​(Y)−nlim​g(n)(x)​=nlim​∫Y​(1−fx(n)​(y))dμ2​=∫Y​(1−fx​(y))dμ2​=μ2​(Y)−g(x).​

    Since μ2(Y)<∞\mu_2(Y) < \inftyμ2​(Y)<∞, lim⁡ng(n)(x)=g(x)\lim_n g^{(n)} (x) = g(x)limn​g(n)(x)=g(x).
    Since they are F1\mathcal{F}_1F1​ measurable, so is g(x)g(x)g(x).

  3. Since 0≤μ2(Y)−∫Yf(n)(x,y)d μ2↑μ2(Y)−∫Yf(x,y)d μ2 0 \le \mu_2(Y) - \int_Y f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \uparrow \mu_2(Y) - \int_Y f(x, y) d\, \mu_2 \,0≤μ2​(Y)−∫Y​f(n)(x,y)dμ2​↑μ2​(Y)−∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​, ∫X∫Yf(n)(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∫Ωf(n)(x,y)d μˉ \int_X \int_Y f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 = \int_{\Omega } f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \bar \mu \,∫X​∫Y​f(n)(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=∫Ω​f(n)(x,y)dμˉ​, and 0≤1−f(n)(x,y)↑1−f(x,y)0 \le 1 - f^{(n)} (x, y) \uparrow 1 - f(x, y)0≤1−f(n)(x,y)↑1−f(x,y), by monotone convergence theorem,

    μ(Ω)−∫X∫Yf(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∫X(μ2(Y)−∫Yf(x,y)d μ2) d μ1=lim⁡n∫X(μ2(Y)−∫Yf(n)(x,y)d μ2) d μ1=μ(Ω)−lim⁡n∫Ωf(n)(x,y)d μˉ=lim⁡n∫Ω(1−f(n)(x,y))d μˉ=∫Ωlim⁡n(1−f(n)(x,y))d μˉ=μ(Ω)−∫Ωf(x,y)d μˉ. \begin{aligned} \mu(\Omega) - \int_X \int_Y f(x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 &= \int_X \left( \mu_2(Y) - \int_Y f(x, y) d\, \mu_2 \right) \, d\, \mu_1 \\ &= \lim_n \int_X \left( \mu_2(Y) - \int_Y f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \right) \, d\, \mu_1 \\ &= \mu(\Omega) - \lim_n \int_{\Omega } f^{ (n) } (x, y) d\, \bar \mu \\ &= \lim_n \int_{\Omega } \left( 1 - f^{ (n) } (x, y) \right) d\, \bar \mu \\ &= \int_{\Omega } \lim_n \left(1 - f^{ (n) } (x, y) \right) d\, \bar \mu \\ &= \mu(\Omega) - \int_{\Omega } f (x, y) d\, \bar \mu. \end{aligned} μ(Ω)−∫X​∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​​=∫X​(μ2​(Y)−∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​)dμ1​=nlim​∫X​(μ2​(Y)−∫Y​f(n)(x,y)dμ2​)dμ1​=μ(Ω)−nlim​∫Ω​f(n)(x,y)dμˉ​=nlim​∫Ω​(1−f(n)(x,y))dμˉ​=∫Ω​nlim​(1−f(n)(x,y))dμˉ​=μ(Ω)−∫Ω​f(x,y)dμˉ​.​

    Observing that μ(Ω)<∞\mu(\Omega) < \inftyμ(Ω)<∞ finishes the proof.

□\square□

Proof Two

Lemma. Given E∈σ(S)E \in \sigma( \mathcal{S} )E∈σ(S), let f(x,y)=IE(x,y)f(x, y) = \mathbb{I}_E (x, y)f(x,y)=IE​(x,y) be the indicator for (x,y)∈E(x, y) \in E(x,y)∈E. Then

  1. For each x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, the function fx(y)≐IE(x,y)f_x(y) \doteq \mathbb{I}_E (x, y)fx​(y)≐IE​(x,y) is F2\mathcal{F}_2F2​ measurable.

  2. The function g(x)≐∫YIE(x,y)d μ2g(x) \doteq \int_Y \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \mu_2g(x)≐∫Y​IE​(x,y)dμ2​ is F1\mathcal{F}_1F1​ measurable.

  3. ∫X∫YIE(x,y)d μ2 d μ1=∫ΩIE(x,y)d μˉ. \int_X \int_Y \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \mu_2 \, d\, \mu_1 = \int_{\Omega } \mathbb{I}_E (x, y) d\, \bar \mu. ∫X​∫Y​IE​(x,y)dμ2​dμ1​=∫Ω​IE​(x,y)dμˉ​.

Proof of (1).

Definition. Let Ex≐{y:(x,y)∈E}E_x \doteq \begin{Bmatrix} y : (x, y) \in E \end{Bmatrix}Ex​≐{y:(x,y)∈E​} be the cross-section at xxx.

It suffices to show that

Claim. For each x∈Xx \in Xx∈X and E∈σ(S)E \in \sigma(\mathcal{S})E∈σ(S), Ex∈F2E_x \in \mathcal{F}_2Ex​∈F2​.

Proof of the Claim.
Fix an x∈Xx \in Xx∈X.
Define the function Tx:Y→X×YT_x : Y \rightarrow X \times YTx​:Y→X×Y by Tx(y)≐(x,y).T_x (y) \doteq (x, y).Tx​(y)≐(x,y).
Then for each E=A×B∈SE = A \times B \in \mathcal{S}E=A×B∈S,

Tx−1(E)=Ex={B, if x∈A,∅, otherwise . T_x^{-1} (E) = E_x = \begin{cases} B, &\text{ if } x \in A, \\ \emptyset, & \text{ otherwise }. \end{cases} Tx−1​(E)=Ex​={B,∅,​ if x∈A, otherwise .​

Therefore Tx−1(E)=Ex∈F2T_x^{-1} (E) = E_x \in \mathcal{F}_2Tx−1​(E)=Ex​∈F2​.
Since S\mathcal{S}S generates σ(S)\sigma(\mathcal{S})σ(S), we conclude that TxT_xTx​ is measurable F2/σ(S)\mathcal{F}_2 / \sigma(\mathcal{S})F2​/σ(S).

□\square□

Proof of (2) and (3).

Define the set L⊆σ(S)\mathcal{L} \subseteq \sigma(\mathcal{S})L⊆σ(S) as the collection of EEE for which the condition (2) and (3) hold.

  1. Clearly it holds that S⊆L\mathcal{S} \subseteq \mathcal{L}S⊆L;
  2. We show that L\mathcal{L}L is a λ\lambdaλ system.

Since S\mathcal{S}S is a π\piπ system, via Dynkin’s π−λ\pi-\lambdaπ−λ theorem, L\mathcal{L}L is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra, and hence L=σ(S)\mathcal{L} = \sigma(\mathcal{S})L=σ(S).

We will now check that L\mathcal{L}L is a λ\lambdaλ-system.
With the same technique applied in previous proof, we can suppose without loss of generality that μ(Ω)<∞\mu(\Omega) < \inftyμ(Ω)<∞.

  1. Ω∈L\Omega \in \mathcal{L}Ω∈L.

  2. If E∈LE \in \mathcal{L}E∈L, then Eˉ∈L\bar E \in \mathcal{L}Eˉ∈L.
    First, observe that Eˉx=Ωx−Ex=B−Ex∈F2\bar E_x = \Omega_x - E_x = B - E_x \in \mathcal{F}_2Eˉx​=Ωx​−Ex​=B−Ex​∈F2​.
    Since μ2(B)<∞\mu_2(B) < \inftyμ2​(B)<∞,

    gEˉ(x)=μ2(Eˉx)=μ2(Ωx−Ex)=μ2(B)−μ2(Ex). g_{\bar E} (x) = \mu_2 ( \bar E_x ) = \mu_2 (\Omega_x - E_x) = \mu_2 (B) - \mu_2 (E_x). gEˉ​(x)=μ2​(Eˉx​)=μ2​(Ωx​−Ex​)=μ2​(B)−μ2​(Ex​).

    Since gE(x)=μ2(Ex)g_E(x) = \mu_2 (E_x)gE​(x)=μ2​(Ex​) is F1\mathcal{F}_1F1​ measurable, so is gEˉ(x)g_{\bar E}(x)gEˉ​(x).
    Integrating over xxx gives

    ∫Xμ2(Eˉx) d μ1=∫Xμ2(B) d μ1−∫Xμ2(Ex) d μ1=μ(Ω)−μ(E). \begin{aligned} \int_X \mu_2 ( \bar E_x ) \, d\, \mu_1 &= \int_X \mu_2 (B) \, d\, \mu_1 - \int_X \mu_2 (E_x) \, d\, \mu_1 \\ &= \mu (\Omega) - \mu(E). \end{aligned} ∫X​μ2​(Eˉx​)dμ1​​=∫X​μ2​(B)dμ1​−∫X​μ2​(Ex​)dμ1​=μ(Ω)−μ(E).​

    Since μ(Ω)<∞\mu(\Omega) < \inftyμ(Ω)<∞, we have μ(Eˉ)=μ(Ω)−μ(E)=∫Xμ2(Eˉx) d μ1\mu(\bar E) = \mu (\Omega) - \mu(E) = \int_X \mu_2 ( \bar E_x ) \, d\, \mu_1μ(Eˉ)=μ(Ω)−μ(E)=∫X​μ2​(Eˉx​)dμ1​.

  3. If En∈L,n∈N+E_n \in \mathcal{L}, n \in \mathbb{N}^+En​∈L,n∈N+ is a disjoint sequence of sets, then ∪n≥1En∈L\cup_{n \ge 1} E_n \in \mathcal{L}∪n≥1​En​∈L. Define gEn(x)≐μ2((En)x)g_{E_n} (x) \doteq \mu_2 ( (E_n)_x )gEn​​(x)≐μ2​((En​)x​).
    Then g(x)≐∑n≥1gEn(x)g(x) \doteq \sum_{n \ge 1} g_{E_n} (x)g(x)≐∑n≥1​gEn​​(x) is F1\mathcal{F}_1F1​ measurable, since g=sup⁡n≥1∑k∈[n]gEkg = \sup_{n \ge 1} \sum_{k \in [n]} g_{E_k}g=supn≥1​∑k∈[n]​gEk​​.
    By monotone convergence theorem and that μ\muμ is a measure, it holds that

    ∫Xg d μ1=∫X∑n≥1gEn d μ1=∑n≥1∫XgEn d μ1=∑n≥1μ(En)=μ(E). \int_X g \, d\, \mu_1 = \int_X \sum_{n \ge 1} g_{E_n} \, d\, \mu_1 = \sum_{n \ge 1} \int_X g_{E_n} \, d\, \mu_1 = \sum_{n \ge 1} \mu (E_n) = \mu (E). ∫X​gdμ1​=∫X​n≥1∑​gEn​​dμ1​=n≥1∑​∫X​gEn​​dμ1​=n≥1∑​μ(En​)=μ(E).

    Therefore, E∈LE \in \mathcal{L}E∈L.

□\square□

Remarks

Given a function f(x,y)f(x, y)f(x,y), there is an easier way to prove that it is measurable F2/B\mathcal{F}_2 / \mathcal{B}F2​/B when xxx is fixed, without approximating it by simple functions.
However, to prove the measurability of ∫Yf(x,y) dμ2\int_Y f(x, y) \, d \mu_2∫Y​f(x,y)dμ2​ (as a function of xxx), we still need to write it as the limit of simple functions.

Lemma. Let f:X×Y→Rf: X \times Y \rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:X×Y→R be measurable σ(S)/B\sigma(\mathcal{S}) / \mathcal{B}σ(S)/B.
For each x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, the function fx:Y→Rf_x : Y \rightarrow \mathbb{R}fx​:Y→R defined by fx(y)=f(x,y)f_x(y) = f(x, y)fx​(y)=f(x,y) is measurable F2/B\mathcal{F}_2 / \mathcal{B}F2​/B.

Proof.
Note that fx=f∘Txf_x = f \circ T_xfx​=f∘Tx​.
Since TxT_xTx​ is measurable F2/σ(S)\mathcal{F}_2 / \sigma(\mathcal{S})F2​/σ(S) and fff is measurable σ(S)/B\sigma(\mathcal{S}) / \mathcal{B}σ(S)/B, it follows that fxf_xfx​ is measurable F2/B\mathcal{F}_2 / \mathcal{B}F2​/B.

Or, specifically, for each Borel set W∈BW \in \mathcal{B}W∈B, since fff is measurable σ(S)/B\sigma(\mathcal{S}) / \mathcal{B}σ(S)/B,

E=f−1(W)={(x,y):f(x,y)∈W}∈σ(S). E = f^{-1} (W) = \{ (x, y) : f(x, y) \in W \} \in \sigma (\mathcal{S}). E=f−1(W)={(x,y):f(x,y)∈W}∈σ(S).

Then

fx−1(W)={y:f(x,y)∈W}=Ex∈F2. f_x^{-1} (W) = \{ y : f(x, y) \in W \} = E_x \in \mathcal{F}_2. fx−1​(W)={y:f(x,y)∈W}=Ex​∈F2​.

□\square□

For completeness, we include a proof for the following fact.
Observe that the technique applied here is similar to the one used in the proof for π\piπ-λ\lambdaλ theorem.

Fact. If S~\tilde{S}S~ is an algebra, then the monotone class M(S~)\mathcal{M}(\tilde{S})M(S~) generated by S~\tilde{S}S~ equals σ(S~)\sigma(\tilde{S})σ(S~).

Proof.
It is trivial to see M(S~)⊆σ(S~)\mathcal{M}(\tilde{S}) \subseteq \sigma(\tilde{S})M(S~)⊆σ(S~).

We prove the other direction by showing that M(S~)\mathcal{M}(\tilde{S})M(S~) is an algebra.
The proof consists of two steps:

  1. For each E∈S~E \in \tilde{S}E∈S~, we prove that

    R(E)≐{F∈M(S~):E∪F,F−E,E−F∈M(S~)}=M(S~). \mathcal{R}(E) \doteq \left\{ F \in \mathcal{M}(\tilde{S}) : E \cup F, F - E, E - F \in \mathcal{M}(\tilde{S}) \right\} = \mathcal{M}(\tilde{S}). R(E)≐{F∈M(S~):E∪F,F−E,E−F∈M(S~)}=M(S~).

    Clearly S~⊆R(E)\tilde{S} \subseteq \mathcal{R}(E)S~⊆R(E).
    We prove that R(E)\mathcal{R}(E)R(E) is a monotone class.
    Suppose that Fn→FF_n \rightarrow FFn​→F is an increasing or decreasing sequence.
    Then E∪Fn,Fn−E,E−FnE \cup F_n, F_n - E, E - F_nE∪Fn​,Fn​−E,E−Fn​ are also increasing or decreasing sequences.
    Therefore, E∪F,F−E,E−F∈R(E)E \cup F, F - E, E - F \in \mathcal{R}(E)E∪F,F−E,E−F∈R(E).

  2. For each E∈M(S~)E \in \mathcal{M}(\tilde{S})E∈M(S~), we prove that

    R(E)≐{F∈M(S~):E∪F,F−E,E−F∈M(S~)}=M(S~). \mathcal{R}(E) \doteq \left\{ F \in \mathcal{M}(\tilde{S}) : E \cup F, F - E, E - F \in \mathcal{M}(\tilde{S}) \right\} = \mathcal{M}(\tilde{S}). R(E)≐{F∈M(S~):E∪F,F−E,E−F∈M(S~)}=M(S~).

    If F∈S~F \in \tilde{S}F∈S~, then the previous claim E∈R(F)E \in \mathcal{R}(F)E∈R(F).
    Therefore, F∈R(E)F \in \mathcal{R}(E)F∈R(E).
    Following similar vein, we can also prove that R(E)\mathcal{R}(E)R(E) is a monotone class.

□\square□
